form.definition: noun K or k is the eleventh letter of the English alphabet.
abbreviation for kilometres. The next town is about 40 k from here.
noun A kaleidoscope is a toy which consists of a tube containing pieces of coloured glass and mirrors. When you look through it, you see colourful symmetrical patterns which change as you turn it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective kaleidoscopic The folk dancers' bright costumes created a kaleidoscopic scene.

form.definition: noun The kangaroo is a native animal of Australia. It has powerful hind legs and a tail for leaping, and a small head and short front legs. The female carries her young in a pouch.
noun Karate is a Japanese style of self-defence which involves fighting without weapons. You use only your hands, feet, elbows and knees.
noun A kayak is a light, covered canoe used in sport.
noun Kebab is the shortened form of shish kebab. A kebab consists of small pieces of grilled meat on a thin stick or skewer.
noun The keel of a boat is the long piece of timber or metal that stretches along the bottom and supports the rest of the frame.
keel over If someone or something keels over, they fall over suddenly. They collapse. Khaled was so weak after his illness, he nearly keeled over as he tried to get out of bed.
adjective Someone who is keen is eager and enthusiastic to do something. I'm keen to try the new restaurant that has just opened. Peter is a keen stamp collectorhe spends many hours on his hobby.
adjective If your senses or feelings are keen, they are clear and strong. Dogs have a keen sense of smell. ...a keen desire.
adjective An edge that is keen is sharp. Be careful how you use that new knifeit has a very keen blade.
keen on If you are keen on someone or something, you are interested in or fond of them. I'm not at all keen on jazz music. Anjali is very keen on her new boyfriend.

verb If someone or something keeps in a particular state or place, they remain in that state or place. I wish they would keep quiet. KEEP LEFT Are you keeping well? The drinks kept cool for quite some time.

verb If someone or something keeps an action going, they continue to do it. She wanted to keep working in the office till the end of the month. They kept him guessing for a long while. The population keeps increasing. b verb If someone or something keeps doing something, they do it over and over again. The wind kept blowing over the pot plants on the veranda. I keep forgetting to post that letter.
verb If you keep something, you retain it. You don't give it away. Our cat had kittenswe kept one and gave the rest away. That's a good photocan I keep it?

verb If you keep someone from doing something, or something from happening, you prevent them doing it or prevent it from happening. We must fix the fence to keep the dog from getting out. Our boss tried to keep the scandal from reaching the headlines. The blinds kept the sun from shining into the room.
verb If you keep a promise or appointment, you carry out what you said you would, or you do what was arranged. I mustn't forget to keep my dental appointment.
verb If you own animals and look after them, you keep them. Vinotha kept a dog all her life. They keep chickens and ducks on their farm.
verb If you keep a record of something, you write it down. Karen kept a diary of her trip. He keeps a list of his expenses. ...keep an account.
verb If food keeps, it remains good. I can't drink all this milkwill it keep till tomorrow?

verb Keep has meanings like 'remain' or 'retain' when it is followed by adverbs such as 'away', 'off' and 'out'. Medicine should be kept away from children. Keep off the grass. PRIVATE PROPERTYKEEP OUT!
noun Your keep is the cost of your needs of living, such as food, clothing and shelter. Sanjay's parents made him work for his keep.
keep at If you keep at something, you continue working at what you have started. You persist with it. I'm sick of this ironing but I'll keep at it till it's finished.
keep back If you keep back information or knowledge, you don't tell it. The witness was uneasy and appeared to be keeping back important facts.

keep down If you keep down the size of something, you stop it from increasing. You do not let it get bigger. The company made a good profit by keeping down costs. Quang keeps his weight down by eating sensibly.

keep to If you keep to something, you carry out what you agreed to do or what is expected of you. Let's keep to our original plan and leave early. Contestants who don't keep to the rules will be disqualified.
keep up (a) If someone or something keeps up with another, they continue at the same speed or rate. I can't keep up with your fast pace. Wages are sure to rise to keep up with inflation.
(b) If you keep up something, you continue to do it. You're making excellent progresskeep up the good work. Amal works long hours to keep up both jobs.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of sense 15 is give up.

form.definition: noun A keeper is someone who guards or looks after things or animals. The keeper has to be careful about changing the diet of the monkeyssome foods seem to make them cranky. ...goalkeeper. ...wicket-keeper. ...housekeeper.
noun If something is in your keeping, it is in your care. I hope the money is safe in your keeping.
in keeping with If something is in keeping with something else, it is suitable for it or in harmony with it. Her modern ideas were in keeping with the times.
noun A keepsake is something that you keep in memory of a person or event. It is like a memento. The ring was a keepsake from her grandmother.
noun A keg is a barrel, especially for storing beer.
noun Kelp is a type of large brown seaweed.
noun A kennel is a house built for a dog to sleep in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb kennel (kennels, kennelled, kennelling) They kennelled their dog when they went on holidays.

form.definition: verb Kept is the past tense and past participle of keep.
noun A kerb is a raised edge of stones or concrete at the side of a street. It separates the footpath from the road.
noun The kernel is the inner part of the hard shell of a nut. You can usually eat it.
noun The kernel is also the central part or core of something. We haven't yet reached the kernel of the problem.
noun Kero is the shortened form of kerosene.
noun Kerosene is a liquid used as a fuel in lamps, heaters and engines.
noun Ketchup is a spicy cold sauce usually made from tomatoes and eaten with meat or sausages.
form.note: ... NOTEThis is an American word. Tomato sauce is the common expression for it in Australian English.

form.definition: noun A kettle is a container for boiling water. It has a handle, a lid, and a spout for easy pouring. I'll put the kettle on so we can make a cup of tea.
noun A key is a small piece of specially shaped metal. It is used to open a lock. I wish I hadn't locked my suitcaseI can't find the key to open it.
noun A key is also used to start a car engine or machinery, and to wind up clocks or toys. Which is the ignition key to the car?

noun The key is something that explains how to understand things such as maps, diagrams or codes. Look in the front of the book for the key to the abbreviations. Where's the key that gives the scale of this map? ...key to the mystery.
noun A key is one of the black and white movable parts on a piano or organ that you press with your fingers to make music.
noun A key is one of the set of parts that you press to use a typewriter or computer.
noun In music, a key is the name given to a series of notes that are related to each other and form the major or minor scales. This piece is written in the key of E minor.

adjective The key part or person in something is the most important one. The key witness for the prosecution will give evidence tomorrow. The key issues of the election campaign are not very clear. ...key industries.
key in If you key in data or instructions into a computer, you enter them by using the keyboard. I had to work back and key in the sales statistics for last month.
keyed up If you are keyed up, you are excited or nervous about something. Leif was very keyed up before his interview.
noun A keyboard is the set of keys on a typewriter, computer or piano.
noun In music, the keynote is the first note of a key or scale.
adjective Keynote is used to describe something that is of main interest. The keynote speaker at the conference was a visiting professor. ...keynote topic.
abbreviation for kilogram or kilograms. She weighs 60 kg.
noun Khaki is a greenish-brown colour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective khaki The soldiers were wearing their khaki uniforms.

form.definition: noun Khmer is a language spoken in Cambodia. It is a member of the Mon-Khmer family of languages.
adjective You also use Khmer to describe someone who is a member of the Khmer Republic.
verb If wheat or grain has been kibbled, it has been ground into small particles.

verb When a person or animal kicks, they strike with their foot. The boys were kicking a ball around the oval. The horse kicked him in the shins. You must kick hard with your legs to be a good swimmer.
noun A kick is a hit or blow with the foot. Sometimes my lawnmower just seems to need a good kick to get it started.

noun In informal language, when you talk about a kick, you mean something which gives you a thrill, or pleases you greatly. She gets a kick out of playing poker machines. Let's go for a midnight swim just for a bit of a kick.

kick out In informal language, if you say you kicked someone out of a job or place, you mean you got rid of them. They kicked him out of the club for swearing. She was kicked out of school for stealing.
kick the bucket In informal language, if you say that someone has kicked the bucket, you mean they have died.
kick the habit In informal language, if you say you have kicked the habit, you mean that you have given up an addiction. Nino doesn't smoke any morehe's kicked the habit.

kick up In informal language, if you say you kicked up a fuss or row, you mean that you caused trouble by complaining loudly about something that has upset you. The service in the restaurant was so slow that people started to kick up a fuss. I know he will kick up a row when he finds out about the ding in his car.

kick yourself If you say you could kick yourself, you mean that you are annoyed with yourself for doing something wrong or stupid. I could have kicked myself for not checking the time of that TV programnow I've missed seeing it.
noun In informal language, you can call a child or young person a kid. Our neighbours have three teenage kids. 2 noun A kid is a young goat.

verb In informal language, if you kid someone, you say things that are not true, as a joke, to trick them. Don't take him seriouslyhe's only kidding. Eva tried to kid them into believing that she had hurt herself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective kid He has a kid sister and an older brother.

form.definition: verb If someone is kidnapped, they are taken away by force and held prisoner. Often money is demanded for their release. Police are looking for the man who kidnapped the small child.
noun Your kidneys are the two organs in your lower back area which remove liquid waste from the blood by producing urine.

verb When someone or something kills a person, animal or plant, they cause them to die. Spiders kill insects for food. Fifty people were killed in the plane crash. Garden pests have killed these plants.
verb If you kill something, you destroy it or end it. He made the wrong decision and killed his chances of promotion. Cold weather is killing our hope of finding the man alive.
verb If you kill time, you occupy yourself with something to make time pass while you are waiting for something else. I always keep a paperback or magazine handy to kill time at airports.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun kill After much stalking, the lion made a kill.noun killer

form.definition: noun A killing is a murder. Police have reported two killings in the last month.
noun A kiln is a large oven for baking bricks or pottery.
noun Kilo is a shortened form of kilogram. She's on a diet trying to lose two kilos.
noun A kilobyte is equal to 1024 bytes of computer information. The symbol for this is K.
noun A kilogram is a unit of weight equal to 1000 grams. The abbreviation for this is kg.
noun A kilohertz is a unit of frequency equal to 1000 cycles per second. The abbreviation for this is kHz.
noun A kilojoule is equal to 1000 joules, which are units used to express the energy value of food. The abbreviation for this is kJ.
noun A kilometre is the unit of length equal to 1000 metres. The abbreviation for this is km.
noun A kilowatt is equal to 1000 watts. The abbreviation for this is kW.
noun A kilt is a short pleated skirt made of tartan cloth and worn mainly by men of the Scottish Highlands.
noun A kimono is a traditional Japanese costume that has wide sleeves, wraps around the body and is tied at the waist.
noun Your kin are the members of your family and your relatives.
adjective Someone who is kind is caring and thoughtful. She was the kindest lady I have ever known. It was kind of you to water our garden while we were away.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is unkind.

form.definition: noun A group of things or people that have similar qualities or are of the same type are a kind. What kind of fruit do you like? The street was littered with all kinds of rubbish. This isn't a good branddo you have another kind?

a kind of or kind of Phrases like a kind of or kind of are used when you are not certain how to describe something or when you are only certain to an extent. I have a kind of idea that might work. She was kind of disappointed.
form.note: ... NOTEA polite way of asking someone to do something for you is to use an expression like Would you be kind enough to... and Would you be so kind as to.... ... WORD FAMILYnoun kindness

form.definition: noun A kindergarten is a school or class that young children around the age of five attend before they go to primary school.
form.note: ... THE SHORTENED FORMof this is kindy.

form.definition: verb If something kindles or you kindle something, it starts to burn or you set it alight. At last the fire began to kindle. A burning cigarette butt had kindled the bushfire.
verb When something arouses or stirs a feeling, you say it kindles it. The lectures were aimed at kindling the interest of the students.
noun Kindling is material, such as dry sticks or leaves, that you use to start a fire. Let's gather some kindling and burn those big logs.
adjective A kindly person is someone who is sympathetic and tries to help. She could always go to her kindly aunt for advice.
adverb If you do something kindly, you do it in a kind manner. He acted kindly towards the strangers. ...to speak kindly.
form.note: ... NOTEYou can use kindly to tell someone in a firm way to stop doing something that annoys you, as in Kindly refrain from smoking. or Will you kindly listen to me?

dictionary.entry: kindred`kIndr@d adjective Things that are kindred are related by a common source or have similar qualities.

form.definition: noun Kindy is the shortened form of kindergarten.
noun A king is a man who rules over a country or empire. He is descended from a royal family. England has been ruled by many kings and queens.
noun Someone of great importance or influence in their field can be called a king. He was the cattle king of the district. ...Tarzan, king of the apes.
noun In the game of chess, the king is the main playing piece.
noun A king is any of the four playing cards with a picture of a king on it.
adjective Something that is king size is very large. They bought a king size bed. How much are king prawns today? ...a king tide.
noun A kingdom is a country ruled by a king or queen.
noun A kingdom is also any of the large divisions in nature such as the animal, plant or mineral kingdoms.
noun A kink is a twist in something like wire, rope, thread or hair. It is hard to comb your hairit is full of kinks. ...a kink in the garden hose.
noun A kink is also something unusual about someone's sexual behaviour.
noun Kinship is the relationship between members of a family. The family tree has revealed some unknown kinships.
noun If you have an understanding with someone or a likeness to them, you have a kinship with them. Bob felt real kinship with the other members of the club.
noun A kiosk is a small shop in a park or at a railway station that sells such things as newspapers, cigarettes, films, snacks and souvenirs.

verb If you kiss someone or something, you touch them with your lips. It is done as a sign of affection or as a greeting. They kissed and said goodbye. Every night she tucks her children into bed and kisses them on the cheek.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun kiss He gave them a kiss on the cheek.

form.definition: noun A kit is a set of tools or articles needed for a special purpose. The scout leader checked the first-aid kit before starting out on the bushwalk. ...repair kit.
noun A kit is a set of parts that need to be put together to make an article. Danny was given a model plane kit for Christmas. ...a do-it-yourself kit.
noun A kitchen is the room or place where food is cooked and prepared.
noun A kitchenette is a small kitchen.
noun A kitchen tea is a party given for a woman who is going to get married. Her friends give her presents for her home.
noun A kite is a toy which consists of a light frame covered with paper or thin cloth. You let it fly in the wind on the end of a long string.
noun Kitsch is showy or worthless art or literature.
noun A kitten is a very young cat.
A kiwi is a small bird of New Zealand that cannot fly.
In informal language, you call a person who comes from New Zealand a kiwi.
abbreviation for kilojoule or kilojoules. A 30 g piece of cheese is equal to 500 kJ.
noun Kleptomania is a mental illness where a person cannot stop themselves from stealing things which they don't really need. It is an impulsive, obsessive action.
abbreviation for kilometre or kilometres. The bridge is 5 km away.
noun A knack is a special skill that you have or that you develop to do a particular thing. Don't give up tryingyou'll soon get the knack of it. He's got a real knack for renovating old furniture.

dictionary.entry: knackered`nAk@d adjective In informal language, if you say you are knackered, you mean you are very tired.

form.definition: noun A knapsack is a canvas or leather bag that you carry on your back. Hikers and climbers usually use them to carry food and clothing.
noun Knave is an old-fashioned word for a man or boy who is not honest.
verb When you knead dough you press, push and stretch it with your hands to get it thoroughly mixed. She was kneading some dough to make bread.
noun Your knee is the joint between the thigh and the lower leg, where it bends. See the picture at body. When you ski you have to bend your knees a lot. Martha was bouncing the baby on her knee.
noun The knee is the part of a pair of trousers that covers the knee. You have worn the jeans through at the knees.
bring to your knees If you say someone or something is brought to their knees, you mean that they are forced to accept defeat. The prolonged recession brought the industry to its knees.
noun Your kneecap is the flat bone at the front of your knee.
verb If you kneel, you rest on one or both knees. The congregation was kneeling in prayer. Emine knelt down by the stream to get a drink of water.
verb Knew is the past tense of know.
noun Knickers are underpants worn by women and girls. She bought herself a pair of knickersthey're frilly and lacy.
noun A knick-knack is a small inexpensive ornament. Their house is full of knick-knacks they've collected over the years.

noun A knife is a tool for cutting things, or it can be a weapon. It has a handle and a sharp blade. We need to set an extra knife and fork on the table for Annie. Don't cut your fingers on the sharp kitchen knife.
verb If you knife someone, you wound them with a knife. The attacker crept up and knifed him in the leg.
noun In the Middle Ages, a knight was a man with a high position in society who fought in wars for the king.
noun In modern times, a knight is a man who has been given the title 'Sir' by a British king or queen for services to his country.
noun In chess, a knight is the piece shaped like a horse's head. ... WORD FAMILYverb knight He was knighted for his bravery.noun knighthood He was very proud of his knighthood.
verb When you knit, you make a garment or fabric from strands of wool or yarn using long needles or a machine. I like to knit while watching TV. She knitted the baby some mittens.
verb If someone or something knits, they join or become closely joined. The plaster cast must stay on your leg till the bones knit. The tragedy had knitted the family more closely together.
noun Knitting is the article that you knit or the act of knitting. Please bring me my knittingit's in the family room. She's got no time for knitting.[qr

dictionary.entry:
knobnOb
noun A knob is a round handle for opening things or for turning things on or off. The new house featured brass knobs on cupboards and doors. Don't let Sally play with the knobs on the radio.
noun A knob is a round lump. The old tree was covered with knobs. The curtain rod had gold knobs at each end. ...a knob of butter.

form.definition: verb If someone or something knocks on a door or window, they tap or strike it. You must knock before you enter. A branch was knocking on the window in the storm.
verb If you knock something, you bump it. She accidentally knocked the vase and spilt the water. In the crush she was knocked against the wall.
verb In informal language, if you say you knock someone or something, you mean you criticise or find fault with them. Why do you always knock my ideas? She was unfairly knocking him about his golf.

knock about (a) If you knock someone or something about, you handle them roughly. He always knocks the dog about when he gets angry. You need a new schoolbagyou've knocked the old one about dreadfully.
(b) If you knock about, you wander from place to place and don'tHe knocked about all over Australia for two years before he settled down in Queensland.
knock around with In informal language, if you say you knock around with someone, you spend time with them as a friend. She knocks around with a group her own age.
knock back (a) If you knock back something, you refuse it. He knocked back an invitation to the cricket match.
(b) If something knocks you back, it puts you in a worse position than you were in before. The holiday will knock us back a few hundred dollars.
knock down (a) If you knock down someone or something, you strike them down to the ground. She was knocked down in the street by a car. They knocked down the old fence and built a new one.
(b) If you knock down the price of something, you reduce it.
(c) In an auction, when a lot is knocked down, it is sold to the highest bidder. Lot 305 was knocked down to Mrs Jones for $95.
knock it off In informal language, you say knock it off when you want to stop something such as an argument or fight. It means 'stop it!'
knock off (a) When you knock off, you stop an activity that you have been doing. He usually knocks off work at 6 o'clock. When do you knock off?

(b) In informal language, if you say someone knocks off something, you mean they steal or rob it. Shop detectives watch out for people knocking off goods. There was another attempt to knock off the bank.
knock on the head When you knock an idea or plan on the head, you put a stop to it. That silly scheme of his will have to be knocked on the head before it goes any further.
knock out (a) When boxers knock out their opponent, they knock them down and defeat them. (b) If someone knocks you out, they make you unconscious by hitting you. A drug can also knock you out.

(c) If you knock yourself out, you tire yourself with too much hard work. I knocked myself out trying to get the job finished before the deadline. (d) If something knocks you out, it stuns you greatly. It impresses you very much. We were knocked out by the grandeur of the occasion.
knock together If you knock together something, you make it quickly and roughly. He knocked together a swing and a seesaw for the kids.
knock up (a) If you knock up someone, you wake them by knocking on their door.
(b) If you knock up something, you arrange or make it in a hurry. How about staying for lunch?I'll knock up some sandwiches.

dictionary.entry:
knotnOt
noun A knot is the part where pieces of thread, string or rope are tied together. Pull the knot tight so it won't come undone. It's hard to get the knots out of this string.
noun A knot in wood is where a branch has joined a tree and left a fault in the grain.
noun A knot is a unit of speed, about equal to 1.85 km/h. The speed of ships, aircraft and wind is measured in knots. The boat was travelling at 25 knots.
... WORD FAMILYverb knot (knots, knotted, knotting) She's knotted this so tightly I haven't got a hope of undoing it.

form.definition: verb If you know something, you understand it to be true or a fact. You are certain in your mind about it. He knew they were away on holidays last month. I know you have a new jobI've known it for a week.
verb If you know something, you have learnt it and can do it. I know how to cook.
verb If you know a person or a place, you are familiar with them. He knew the city well ten years ago, but it has changed. They won't leave earlyI know them, they'll stay till the very end.
I know People often use I know to show that they suddenly have an idea. What can we do in the holidays that's different?I know, let's go mining for opals at Lightning Ridge.
in the know If you are in the know about something, you have inside information which other people do not have. He's in the know or he wouldn't have sold those shares when he did.

know backwards You say you know something backwards if you know it or understand it very well. She had recited the poem so many times that she knew it backwards. He could never get lost in this placehe knows it backwards.
let someone know If you let someone know about something, you tell them about it. Let me know when you need the book back. If we're running late, we'll let you know.

you know You know is often used in conversation to keep it flowing or to keep the listener interested. It doesn't always have much meaning. They're really nice people, you know, but they're always short of money. You know, I've been wondering what to do...
adjective A knowing look or remark is one that shows that you have a secret understanding of something, more than is obvious. He turned his head and gave us a knowing wink.
adjective Someone who is knowing is intelligent and wise.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb knowingly It wasn't an accidenthe did it knowingly.

form.definition: noun Your knowledge is the experience and facts you have gained or learnt through living and studying. It is what you know. He has a vast knowledge of marine animals. She doesn't seem to have much knowledge about bringing up children.
noun Knowledge is the awareness of a fact or happening. She had no knowledge of his disappearance.

to the best of your knowledge If you say that something is the case to the best of your knowledge, you mean that you think it is true but you are not completely sure. The outdoor concert will take place, to the best of my knowledge, regardless of the weather.
verb Known is the past participle of know.
noun Your knuckles are your finger joints.
knuckle down If you knuckle down to a task, you work hard at it. It's about time she knuckled down and completed her diploma.
abbreviation for knockout.
noun A koala is a furry, grey, Australian animal that lives and feeds in certain types of gum tree.
noun A kookaburra is an Australian bird with a harsh call which sounds like laughter. It eats mainly fish.
form.note: ... OTHER NAMESfor this bird are laughing kookaburra and laughing jackass.

form.definition: noun Korean is the language of the people of Korea.
adjective You can also use Korean to describe someone or something that comes from Korea.
adjective Kosher is used to describe food, especially meat, that has been prepared according to Jewish law. Is this food kosher? ...a kosher restaurant.
noun Kung-fu is a style of fighting without weapons. It is a Chinese form of karate.[fa[xp
